title: 113_hr3521
content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Veterans Affairs Major Medical Facility Lease Authorization Act of 2013" and authorizes major medical facility leases. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility leases at specified locations with maximum amounts for each lease, including a clinical research center in Albuquerque, New Mexico ($9,560,000), a community-based clinic in Brick, New Jersey ($7,280,000), a primary care and dental clinic annex in Charleston, South Carolina ($7,070,250), and a community-based Outpatient Clinic in Cobb County, Georgia ($6,409,000). The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility leases at specified locations with maximum amounts for each lease, including Honolulu, Hawaii ($15,887,370), Johnson County, Kansas ($2,263,000), Lafayette, Louisiana ($2,996,000), Lake Charles, Louisiana ($2,626,000), New Port Richey, Florida ($11,927,000), and Ponce, Puerto Rico ($11,535,000) for various outpatient clinics and facilities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility leases at specified locations with maximum amounts for each lease, including Honolulu, Hawaii, Johnson County, Kansas, Lafayette, Louisiana, Lake Charles, Louisiana, New Port Richey, Florida, and Ponce, Puerto Rico. Additionally, funds are allocated for lease consolidation in San Antonio, Texas, a community-based outpatient clinic in San Diego, California, an outpatient clinic in Tyler, Texas, the Errera Community Care Center in West Haven, Connecticut, the Worcester community-based Outpatient Clinic in Worcester, Massachusetts, the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic in Cape Girardeau, Missouri, a multispecialty clinic in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic. For the expansion of community-based outpatient clinics in Chico, California ($4,534,000), Chula Vista, California ($3,714,000), Lincoln, Nebraska ($7,178,400), Lubbock, Texas ($8,554,000), and Myrtle Beach, South Carolina ($8,022,000). Also, for new and replacement research leases in Hines, Illinois ($22,032,000) and Houston, Texas ($6,142,000) respectively. In addition to funding for various community-based outpatient clinics in different states, including California, Nebraska, Texas, and South Carolina, there is also funding allocated for the expansion of clinics in Phoenix, Arizona, Redding, California, and Tulsa, Oklahoma. The amounts allocated for these expansions range from $8,154,000 to $20,757,000. SEC. 3. Budgetary treatment of Department of Veterans Affairs major medical facilities leases. Congress finds that the Department of Veterans Affairs must record the full cost of contractual obligations against available funds when a contract is executed. Office of Management and Budget Circular A-11 guides agencies in meeting statutory requirements for leases. For operating leases, the Department of Veterans Affairs must record upfront budget authority equal to total payments under the lease term or sufficient to cover first-year payments and cancellation costs, subject to appropriations provided in advance. In exercising the authority to enter into leases, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs must record the full cost of the contractual obligation at the time of execution. This includes total payments under the lease term or first-year payments and cancellation costs if the lease is terminated early. Transparency in funding proposals is required by law. When proposing funding for a major medical facility lease, a detailed analysis must be provided on how the lease will comply with Office of Management and Budget Circular A-11 and the Anti-Deficiency Act. This analysis includes classifying the lease as lease-purchase, capital lease, or operating lease, assessing budgetary obligations, and determining asset cost, fair market value, and cancellation costs. Before entering into a major medical facility lease, the Secretary must provide notice to Congress, including details of the lease, differences from the initial proposal, and a scoring analysis to show compliance with Office of Management and Budget Circular A-11. Congress must review and ensure the information provided meets the requirements. The committee treats information submitted with confidentiality and penalties for unauthorized disclosure. The Secretary must report any differences in a major medical facility lease to Congress within 30 days. This section does not relieve the Department of Veterans Affairs from existing obligations. The section does not relieve the Department of Veterans Affairs from regulatory obligations or requirements existing prior to its enactment and any amendments. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives. Passed by the House of Representatives on December 10, 2013.
